sp.p: Hold Sir, I beseech you. Fear nothing, Mr Gerald. [aside

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: You shall see presently.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: 'Tis just like one of our Butchers Knives: and then what is that Ax for?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Dis be de decolation Ax, to cut off de head at one Chop; as thus—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Not yet Sir: What's that there like a Wimble?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Dat be to bore a hole in de Scull; when any part of de Scull be broke, and depress'd upon de Brain, with dis we bore hole hard by de fracture, as you shall see just-a-now.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: No Sir, not now; I'll see't anon.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Den we put in de proper Instrument, and raise de depressure up to de proper place, and so make de cure.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: But what is this terrible Saw for?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Dat be de dismembring Saw, to Saw off de Leg, or de Arm: You see me presentale Saw off de Bone of dis Leg, and—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Stay Sir; What's that sharp crooked Knife for?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Dis be de Amputation Knife, to cut off de Leg or de Hand, just-a in de Joynt. Ha! where be de Leg and be Arm?—

div.stage: Crispin draws one Leg from the other, and one Arm from his Body, and Gerald draws 'em close to him again.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: De Devil! me lay one Arm here, and one Leg here, to Saw off just in the middle, and cut off just in de Joynt, for de fine experiment; and de Arm, and de Leg, be gone home to de Body.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Mr Dr. we come for the Coffin we brought the dead Body in.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Dere be de Coffin; be gone; and give me no interruption; now I open all de Breast. [Cris. tears open his Wastcoot. So, now with dis Instrument, dis [The men carry off the Coffin. Knife, I will in one moment cut de Breast-bone, from de Ribs, and lay all open, dat you shall see how de Heart, de Lungs, de Liver, lie in dair place proper, and order natural. O de Devil, agen! de Body shrink! de Leg move; and de Arm too: vat strange Carcass have you in dis Country?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, I have seen whole Bodies, after they have lain here a day or two, get up, and run away.

sp.speaker: O. Ger.
sp.p: And so will I! I'll not stay to be butcher'd here. He leaps off the Table.

sp.speaker: Cris, & Bea.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: O. Ger.
sp.p: Lose my Cloaths, my Life, and Jewels all at once!— Your Servant, Mr Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Stop Thief, stop Thief. As old Gerald is running out, and Crispin after him, the Doctor and his Wife enter. O. Gerald runs against the Doctor, beats the Doctor and his Wife down, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: O murder, murder!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ay, murder, murder!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Wounds! Where's this Dog of a Doctor? I'le knock the old Cheat's Brains out.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: And if I can reach him, I'le claw his Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: O am bruis d all over!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And I am lam'd too.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: O are you there?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Wounds, Doctor, you have scour'd my Guts out, with a murrain to ye—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: And I can hardly draw my Legs after me, for your Physick. But I'le claw you for't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Hold, Mistress, or I shall pluck a Crow with you.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Be patient Wife— you are both mad. I never saw either of you before.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: O damn'd lying Doctor! did you not give me Pills? and I gave you a whole half Guinea?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: And had not I some of your Rot-gut Pills too, and gave you 2 new Crown-pieces?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: You rave both, and must be sent to Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: 'Sbud I'le have my money again—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: And so will I,— or tear his Eyes out—

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Hold friends! pray moderate your angers, and don't affront a person of our faculty.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ah, ha! I was mistaken, this is the Doctor—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: I this is he gave us the Pills. I beg your pardon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Beatrice, you must refund.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: There—

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Look you friends, 'twas a mistake. There's your Half Guinea, and your Crown-pieces too.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: O pox! this is something.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: What is the meaning of all this▪

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Beatrice, what is the matter here?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: What strange out-cry was that we heard?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I, and who threw us down?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: And what strange thing was that ran over us?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p:
Why, Sir, as I was shewing Mr Doctor here the
dead Body that was sent you from the Gallows, he felt his pulse, and laying his hand on his Breast, he found his Heart panted; then he took his Incision Knife, and before he could touch his naked skin, up started the dead Body, and ran away, just as you saw—

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: All this is true, Sir, as I am a Member of the learned Faculty.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I am amaz'd▪

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay Husband, I have heard of such strange things: I warrant the poor man was hang'd wrongfully.

sp.speaker: O. Ger.
sp.p: O undone! undone!

sp.speaker: Wife & Bea.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: He's come again, Husband, ha!

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: In the name of goodness! What art thou?

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: Undone I say, undone.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Art thou a Spirit? or Flesh and Blood? answer.

sp.speaker: O. G
sp.p: Give me my Cloaths, my Jewels, Huswife—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Avant, avant!

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: Where are they? Gipsy, speak.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: In the Coffin, in the Coffin.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: I overtook the Coffin, and there's none of 'em. Where are they, and the Jilt too your young Mistress?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Sure 'tis our Neighbour, Mr Gerald.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: I am the same.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You tell me wonders, Crispin.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Step to your Daughter's Chamber, Madam; there the Riddle will easily be unfolded▪

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: What is the matter, Sir? why in this posture? and why this out-cry too?

sp.speaker: O. O.
sp.p: That Baggage there, and the young Witch your Daughter, have contriv'd to abuse and cheat me, of two thousand pounds worth of Jewels, that were pawnd to me.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Here they come then, who must give you satisfaction.

div.stage: Enter Wife and Young Gerald, leading in Angelica, dress'd in the Jewels.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: How! my Son here!

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and my Wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I found 'em shut up together in my Daughter's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Married say you?

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, contracted long since; and now confirm'd in private, as far as modesty would permit.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: And Married too! then all is at an end.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: Here are your Cloaths, Sir, Doctor Crispin can tell you how I came by 'em.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Crispin!

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: My Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Non Rogus; Medicus sum; that is, I am a German, or a Polish Doctor.

sp.speaker: Y. G.
sp.p: The Jewels, Sir, so well become my Wife, I think you cannot in conscience demand 'em back.

sp.speaker: Ang▪
sp.p: They were his own free gift; he scorns to take what he has given me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Well. I am glad the Son has married my Daughter, and wish Joy to you both.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Bless you together. Come Brother Gerald, 'tis your Son's Wedding Night; you must forgive 'em and be sociable: Let me prevail with you to give order for a good Supper, and we'll be very merry, Brother.

sp.speaker: O. G.
sp.p: I had as good, I shall be laught at else.
Sirrah▪ here has been fine practice, and my Son's marriage was your contrivance.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I do confess it, Sir, and glory in the success.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Come then, sit down, and listen to the Musick, and after Supper we'll hear at large the adventures of Doctor Crispin in this Affair.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Beatrice and I will tell you he whole Story,
And as we snack'd the Fees, we'll share the Glory.

div.stage: The Fourth and last Musical Entertainment. After that, the Curtain falls.
